titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the G. Evelyn Hutchinson Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Diane E. Kaplan

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 07:19

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of correspondence, writings, addresses, notes and research materials, subject files, memorabilia, and photographs relating to G. Evelyn Hutchinson's work as a zoologist and limnologist. The papers highlight his years on the faculty at Yale University but also document his student days at Cambridge University and his early career in South Africa. Of note are materials from his travels as part of the Yale North India Expedition. The collection includes personal papers relating to various members of the Hutchinson family.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of G. Evelyn Hutchinson, 1950s-1990; Robert Cook, 1983 and 1990; the estate of G. Evelyn Hutchinson, 1991-1992; Yvette H. Edmondson, 1992; Nancy Slack, 1997 and 2009; and Dorothea and Francis Hutchinson, 1998; and transferred from Kline Science Library, 1991 and 2006.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is available for research. Some correspondence with Robert H. MacArthur is restricted until 2035.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to Yale University for any copyright Nancy Slack may have in Accession 2009-M-082. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: G. Evelyn Hutchinson Papers (MS 649). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: G. Evelyn Hutchinson Papers Relating to Rebecca West. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: George Evelyn Hutchinson was born in Cambridge, England, on January 30, 1903. His father, Arthur Hutchinson, was a mineralogist and master of Pembroke College at Cambridge University. Hutchinson's early education was at St. Faith's School, Cambridge, and Gresham's School, Holt. He demonstrated an early interest in natural history, particularly butterflies and aquatic insects, and published his first piece of scholarship when he was fifteen.

Hutchinson was a member of Emmanuel College as an undergraduate and received a B.A. from Cambridge University in 1924. After graduation he spent a year as a Rockefeller Fellow at the Stazione Zoologica in Naples where he studied octopus, squid, and other deep sea animals of Messina but also became fascinated with folklore and art. In 1926 Hutchinson accepted his first academic job as a senior lecturer in zoology at the University of the Witwatersrand in South Africa, where he began his studies of the physical, biological, chemical, and meteorological conditions of lakes of the western Transvaal. In 1928, he married Grace Pickford.

In that same year, Hutchinson made his final career move, joining the faculty of Yale University as an instructor. He rose to become Sterling Professor of Zoology, a post he held until his retirement in 1971. In 1932, Hutchinson was given the opportunity to study the ecosystems of the lakes on the high plateaus of Tibet, as the biologist accompanying the Yale North India Expedition. Hutchinson chronicled his impressions and experiences in The Clear Mirror (1936). On the return trip from India, he met Margaret Seal, who became his second wife in 1933.

Hutchinson is best known for his work in limnology, the study of freshwaters, particularly lakes. Early on he recognized the significance of ecology, and much of his research and writing dealt with the relationship between living organisms and their environment. He was particularly interested in the determining influence of the physical and chemical environment on the ecology of rivers and lakes. In 1935, he demonstrated the importance of horizontal movements of water in stratified lakes in mixing the upper and lower layers of water. In other studies he showed the circulation of phosphorous in stratified lakes and conducted research on the chemistry of lake sediments. In 1957, he published the first volume of his A Treatise on Limnology , a work of such extensive and thorough analysis that it comprised four volumes, the last of which was released posthumously.

Hutchinson had vast theoretical insight and defended the importance of theory as a stimulus to empirical research. In his desire to find order in the diversity of nature, he maintained that there was a need for dialogue between mathematicians and biologists and he employed mathematical models to arrive at general principles. His curiosity and ability to pose stimulating questions on ecological principles inspired his students, many of whom became leading figures in ecology. He asked, and partially answered the question, "Why are there so many kinds of animals?" and he provided a theoretical understanding of how an organism fits in nature, giving a modern definition of the ecological niche. A prolific writer, Hutchinson presented some of his most provocative ideas in his "Marginalia" column in American Scientist .

Hutchinson was an active participant in numerous professional organizations and learned societies. He was a charter member of the Limnological Society of America and its president from 1947 to1948. Elected to the National Academy of Sciences in 1950, he served on its Committee on Science and Public Policy and was a foreign member of the Royal Society. He received several honorary degrees, and his contributions were recognized by, among others, the Naumann Medal of the International Association of Theoretical and Applied Limnology (1959), the Frederick Garner Cottrell Award for Environmental Quality of the National Academy of Sciences (1974), the Daniel Giraud Elliot Medal of the National Academy of Sciences (1984), and the Kyoto Prize in Basic Science (1986).

Hutchinson is remembered as a shy, reserved man, with an insatiable curiosity about all fields of human inquiry and a delightful sense of humor. His wife Margaret had died in 1983, and he had married Anne Twitty in 1985. After her death in 1990, Hutchinson, in failing health, had returned to England. He died there on May 17, 1991.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The G. Evelyn Hutchinson Papers are a large, yet incomplete, record of the personal life and professional career of a giant in the field of limnology. The papers attest to Hutchinson's long and inspirational career as a scholar and teacher, who shaped the development of the emerging field of ecology. Moreover they demonstrate his broad interests from the Abraxas butterfly and water striders in the insect world, the sexual behavior of birds, and mathematical modeling, to British stamps, medieval art, Guernsey archaeology, ancient inscriptions on Tibetan rocks, and the art and architecture of India and Goa.

While there is material, including correspondence, writings, and photographs, from Hutchinson's youth in England through his tenure at Yale, the bulk of the collection dates from the years following his retirement in 1971. Hutchinson continued to be intellectually active in these years, producing the third and fourth volumes of A Treatise on Limnology and "Marginalia" columns. Both the correspondence and the writings series contain material on these endeavors.

Included in the papers are letters from the most prominent academicians in ecology as well as materials for professional societies in their fledgling years. The large number of files for students, colleagues, and organizations attests to his impact on the field. A supportive mentor, the papers document Hutchinson's continuing role in furthering the careers of his students, both men and women, and his interest in their scholarly pursuits. The papers do not include materials such as course syllabi or lecture notes from Hutchinson's teaching, but there is some documentation relating to the Yale science curriculum.

The papers include copious files concerning Hutchinson's publications and speeches, most notably his A Treatise on Limnology . It is, however, difficult to trace the progress of Hutchinson's inquiry and observation on the condition of lakes or the variation in animal species from the relatively limited amount and disorderly state of research data retained by him. Perhaps the best documented of his scholarly endeavors is his work on the Yale North India Expedition in 1932. Letters to his parents and to Grace Pickford, from this period, abound with detail, and every other series in the papers contains some material from this exploration. Hutchinson was a member of the Episcopal Church, and some of his correspondence and writings he explore perceived conflicts between science and religion. In his later writings, he also examines the depiction of nature in art.

The papers include personal materials, but in selecting materials to make available for research, Hutchinson made a deliberate effort to protect his privacy and that of others. There is little in the papers, for instance, concerning his marriages. In preparing to write of his early years and development, a work that would become The Kindly Fruits of the Earth , Hutchinson amassed materials on his parents and their families along with his letters and memorabilia from his student days and travels. These materials provide insight into the milieu which gave rise to Hutchinson's intellectual curiosity about the world.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in five series and two additions: I. Correspondence, 1904-1991. II. Topical Files, 1927-1992. III. Research and Writings, 1922-1991. IV. Personal Files, 1916-1991. V. Photographs, 1875-1991.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is composed of both incoming and outgoing exchanges with correspondents who include some of the most eminent scholars both in the United States and around the globe, as well as family and personal friends. The correspondence files also document the organization and development of numerous professional organizations and their work as spokesmen to the public. The series is arranged alphabetically by the personal or corporate name of the correspondent.

The bulk of the correspondence dates after 1940, but there are a few letters dating from Hutchinson's years at Cambridge and in South Africa. While not obviously lacking correspondence for any particular year, the series bulks larger for the period after Hutchinson's retirement in 1971. While one would expect a larger quantity of material from the period of Hutchinson's active teaching career, by comparison with the post retirement period, the letters from the 1940s through the 1960s seem diminished, as if Hutchinson had either saved less during these years or had lost or weeded files at some later date.

Reviewing the names of Hutchinson's correspondents begins to suggest the size of his intellectual network and the variety of his interests. Not surprisingly many of them are in biology and other fields related to ecology and because of his education and research interests, several are from England and Italy: Enrico Bonati, Paul Colinvaux, Paul Ehrlich, Clyde Goulden, Arthur Hassler, Julian Huxley, David Lack, Luigi Provalosi, Vittorio and Livia Tonolli. There is also correspondence with Russian colleagues G. F. Gauze and Nicholai Formozov, as well as exchanges with Yale colleagues Leo Buss, John Buettner Janusch, Raymond Lindeman, Donald Poulson, and George Vernadsky. R. A. McConnell's correspondence describes his work on ESP and parapsychology and his attempts to publish it for a scholarly audience. Hutchinson shared comradery and intellectual challenges with a number of women, including Ruth Patrick, Lynn Margulis, Phoebe Ellsworth, Mary Gritten, Donna Haraway, Penelope Jenkin, Sharon Kingsland, Lorraine Larison, Estella Leopold, Margaret Mead, Sharon Ohlhorst, Miriam Rothschild, and Marjorie Garber.

Some of Hutchinson's major correspondents are former graduate students, many of whom became leading figures in ecology. The correspondence documents the important influence Hutchinson had in their development, and the files for R. J. Benoit, Vaughn Bowen, John L. Brooks, Alan Covich, Edward Deevey, W. Thomas Edmondson, Thomas Goreau, Louis Hutchins, Thomas Lovejoy, Robert MacArthur, Howard Odum, Gordon Riley, Lawrence Slobodkin, and J. R. Vallentyne may include comments on their work, suggestions for further development of their ideas, references for jobs, and other professional concerns, as well as personal messages concerning family and travel. In his post retirement years, the files include correspondence about manuscripts on which Hutchinson advised or worked cooperatively with several associates and students, including Ursula Cowgill, Myrdene Anderson, Karen Porter Glaus, Alison Jolly, Eleanora Robbins, and Saran Twombly. There is also a considerable amount of correspondence with Yvette Edmondson concerning the publication of the fourth volume of A Treatise on Limnology .

Hutchinson took a leading role in organizations such as the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia, the American Society of Limnology and Oceanography, the Conservation Foundation, the International Association of Theoretical and Applied Limnology, and the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia, and files for each of them document this activity. The files for the National Academy of Sciences are particularly large, attesting to Hutchinson's work on awards committees, the Environmental Studies Board, nominating committees, and the Reports Review Committee, the latter concerning debate over the appropriate position to take on the effects of herbicide use in Vietnam. There is also significant correspondence concerning the nation's natural history museums, including the Smithsonian and the American Museum of Natural History in New York. The correspondence with S. Dillon Ripley and Philip C. Ritterbush is notable in this regard.

There are numerous letters written by Hutchinson to his family. Those from the Yale North India Expedition are particularly vivid. To his parents, Arthur and Evaline Hutchinson, Hutchinson wrote of his travels, while to Grace Pickford in New Haven, he sent more scientific and expedition details, as well as discussions of their private life. These letters contain verbal descriptions of photographs found in Series V. A large file of fragmentary letters written during the expedition is filed with the unidentified correspondence at the end of the series. There is a large correspondence with Hutchinson's sister Dorothea who lived with Hutchinson's mother. Occasionally both mother and sister wrote joint letters, and these are filed with the correspondence of Dorthea.

During World War II, Hutchinson and his wife welcomed to their home Yemaiel Oved, the young daughter of his friend Gwendolyn Hughes, to protect her from the bombing taking place over England. The personal correspondence of Hughes and Oved is interesting in this regard. Yemaiel was like a child the Hutchinsons never had, and she maintained contact as she married, changed her name to Aris, and began raising her own family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is composed of correspondence, notes, reports, and other types of materials, which Hutchinson collected together by subject. The files are arranged alphabetically bu subject. The series reflects the wide and varied nature of Hutchinson's personal and professional interests and includes files on the Yale North India Expedition, various grant proposals on which Hutchinson worked, Yale curriculum materials, manuscripts by others, and Hutchinson's stamp collecting. Hutchinson's forays into public policy debates can be seen in his files on the Aldabra Islands in the Indian Ocean. Efforts of environmentalists such as Hutchinson helped secure this area as a nature preserve protecting giant tortoises. Hutchinson's early interest in geochemistry is evident in the titles of his various grant proposals but also in the typescript of the English translation of "Chemical Elements and Ions in the Crust of the Earth" by the noted Russian scientist Aleksandr Fersman. The series also includes a typescript of a work by the Russian microbiologist G. F. Gauze.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes materials related to Hutchinson's research and writings. They are organized in sections: articles and essays; books; lectures and speeches; notes; research notebooks; and writings, unpublished. The series does not include research grant proposals, which are in Series II. It also does not include copies of any of Hutchinson's publications, which are widely available. Hutchinson compiled a listing of his published works, other than books, as part of the process of creating bound volumes of his "Collected Papers." These bound volumes are available in the Yale University Kline Science Library. Most of the separately published articles and pamphlets that the volumes contain would also be available in the original journals.

The listing for the contents of the "Collected Papers" served as an authority for organizing materials in the first section in the series, articles and essays. There are far more titles on the list than are represented by the materials in the section. The early years of Hutchinson's career are particularly under represented. Since the volumes of "Collected Papers" do not include lectures and speeches, there is a separate section for typescripts and notes for these. They are arranged in chronological order according to delivery date. Where known the title is given, but many speeches are identified only by place of delivery, event, or topic.

Materials associated with other titles not found on the list of "Collected Papers" are organized in the Writings, unpublished section. It is possible that some manuscripts in this section may be chapter drafts or other sections of a larger work which were renamed in the later published version. Other materials may be for "Marginalia" columns, reports, or possibly lectures. Folder descriptions in which the title is enclosed in quote marks indicate either a title found on the manuscript or in Hutchinson's handwriting on the original Folder. Other Folder headings give the general topic of the manuscript. Folders are arranged alphabetically by title or topic, with a few Folders of material arranged by type at the end of the section.

More materials of similar appearance but without any title are arranged under the heading "Loose pages." These handwritten or typed pages appear to be drafts of sections or fragments of writings. Often the pages are numbered sequentially, but the manuscript commences on a page other than 1. Because the pages could not be attributed to a particular work they have been left as found in seemingly random order. Included in some Folders are photocopies of the original Folders on which Hutchinson scrawled notes. These have been retained in an effort to help the researcher identify the contents of the Folder. Some of these proved to be identification of only the first item in the Folder and not of other materials that were filed farther on. It is quite possible that any Folder may contain pages from unrelated manuscripts, either published or unpublished. There may also be pages that more closely resemble materials found in the notes section of research materials. This has led to a larger than usual amount of material which has been tentatively identified, left unidentified, or possibly misidentified.

The collected data and observations in the sections Notes and Research notebooks suggest the breadth of Hutchinson's scientific interests including butterflies, aquatic insects, guano found on islands, the archaeology of Guernsey, various lakes, and biogeochemistry. The Notes section includes materials similar in appearance to the "Loose pages." These are arranged by topic, and some of this material is associated with courses Hutchinson gave during his long teaching career.

The section Books includes drafts and notes for Hutchinson's many books. The manuscripts for the A Treatise on Limnology , the magnum opus which Hutchinson published in four volumes over a period of more than thirty years, are the most voluminous, with those for the last volume being the most extensive as well as the least well organized. The handwritten manuscripts and typescripts reflect the development of Hutchinson's ideas for the work over many years. In the evolution, he created numerous versions for many sections, interleaving pages from handwritten drafts with subsequent typed material. Many pages are heavily annotated and some bear as many as three different chapter numbers with as many different page numbers.

Because serious work to complete the fourth volume began when Hutchinson was already in his eighties, he needed the assistance of numerous individuals, particularly Yvette Edmondson and Anna Aschenbach. The files reflect their efforts to decipher Hutchinson's editorial comments and include some correspondence between them, which was generated in the process. Since most of the drafts are undated, the files for this volume could not be organized to trace the development of each chapter, and the files are undifferentiated beyond the form of the material as typescript or handwritten.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains Hutchinson's personal papers, which include biographical information and materials relating to his family history, his parents and his wives. There are also numerous files documenting awards and honors Hutchinson received and celebrations in his honor. The memorabilia files also include a scrapbook of photographs and drawings from Hutchinson's early travels in Italy. Student notebooks in the series date from Hutchinson's years at Cambridge University.

did.unittitle: New Haven Festival of the Arts
National Academy of Sciences' Award for Environmental Quality in honor of Frederick Gardner Cottrell
National Academy of Sciences' Daniel Giraud Elliot Medal
Italy [scrapbook of photographs, drawings, and postcards]
National Academy of Sciences centennial celebration

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes photographs that document Hutchinson's personal life and professional career. The earliest photographs are of family members, but there are numerous pictures of Hutchinson as a young child. There are many other photographs of people and events in Hutchinson's life, including a pictorial record of the childhood and adult life of Yemaiel Oved Aris. The images from Hutchinson's travels and research, particularly those taken as part of the Yale North India Expedition, are especially noteworthy.

did.unittitle: Marsh Lecture and Verrill Award ceremony

odd.head: General
odd.p: See also: Series IV, box 104, folder 38

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transferred from Kline Science Library, Yale University, 2006.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This accession comprises articles written by G. Evelyn Hutchinson.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: Photocopies and notecards (1 linear foot) containing readily available bibliographic information on scientific literature were removed from the collection during processing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This accession comprises a small amount of correspondence to and from Hutchinson, notes and drafts relating to his professional writings, and an album of photographic negatives documenting part of Hutchinson's trip on the Silk Road in the border region between India and Tibet.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: Unstable cellulose nitrate negatives contained in this album were removed, digitized, and then destroyed. The album itself was retained because of the informative notes it contains relating to some of the images.
